The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he believed he had paid his master every thing he had received, and if not it must arise from error.
GUILTY . Aged 53.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1679.
WILLIAM WEST
was indicted for
embezzlement .

MARY CLARKE
. I am a widow , and keep a marine store shop , in the parish of St. Margaret, Westminster; the prisoner was in my employ, and received money for me. I sent him to Mrs. Mackley, on the 2d of July, to see some rags weighed off, and to bring me back 10l. 16s. and some few pence - he never came back.
Prisoner. Q. Was I sober when I went? A. I thought so.

SARAH MACKLEY
. I paid the prisoner 10l. 16s. 4d. on the 2d of July, on account of Mrs. Clarke; it was a 5l. note, the rest in gold and silver. I thought him rather stupid, but not intoxicated.
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Confined One Year .

1680.
CHARLES POPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of February , 1 pair of boots, value 20s. , the goods of
Joseph Borsley
, his master .
MR. PRENDERGAST conducted the prosecution.

CHARLES OGLE
. I am a tailor and live in North Audley-street. I have bought boots of the prisoner, but I do not know whether he delivered them to me; here is a pair I ordered of him - I do not know whether he brought them to my house.

JOHN LACY
. I am an officer. I have a pair of boots here, which Mr. Borsley cannot swear to.

Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. When did you apprehend the prisoner? A. On the 15th of July. I do not know of his being tried here that day for stealing these very boots. I took him to Mary-le-bone office, and they ordered him to Marlborough-street, as the first case was taken there.
NOT GUILTY .

1681.
ELIZA COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 1 bushel of apples, value 3s., and 1 basket, value 9d. , the goods of
Thomas Poole
.

THOMAS GIBSON
. I am servant to
Thomas Poole
, of Covent-garden. I was told the prisoner had taken a basket of apples from the stand - I went and found her with them; they were safe five minutes before.(Basket produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I thought I paid for them - I did not intend to steal them.
GUILTY . Aged 47.
Confined One Month .

1682.
JOHN BUSKIN
and
ROBERT THRELKED
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Jacob Myers
, from his person .

JACOB MYERS
. I was in the Strand
on the 31st of August, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I felt some person at my pocket, turned round, and saw Whittingham holding Threlked by the collar.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You did not see the handkerchief taken? A. No; I missed it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM WHITTINGHAM
. I was in the Strand, and saw the prisoners in company; I could not see which of them took the handkerchief, but I saw Threlked putting it into his pocket - I rushed up, and seized him - he dropped it at his feet; Buskin ran away, but a friend who was with me followed, and took him a few yards off; Buskin said he hoped I should be lenient.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it dark? A. Yes - the lampswere lighted; I was very near them - they were so close together I could not see which took it.
THRELKED'S Defence. I picked up the handkerchief, and called to the gentleman.

THRELKED -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months .

BUSKIN -
NOT GUILTY .

1683.
THOMAS HAWKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 1 bedstead, value 10s. , the goods of
William Kennedy
.

SARAH KENNEDY
. I am the wife of
William Kennedy
, who is a broker - we live in Little St. Andrew-street
. On the 25th of August the prisoner came into the shop, and offered some razors for sale, which I would not buy; he went out, and stood about the door; my daughter called out,"Mother, have you sold a bedstead?" I said No; we ran out, and took the prisoner in Little Earl-street, with it on his shoulder; it had been tied to a nail in our passage.

MARY KENNEDY
. I saw the prisoner standing about, and missed the bedstead; we found the prisoner with it.

JAMES LEDGER
. I am an officer, and stopped him with the bedstead on his back.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry it for him.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined Six Months .

1684.
ELIZA RILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 hat, value 12s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Bridges
.

ROBERT BRIDGES
. I met the prisoner in the Hay-market, on the 31st of July, and she took me to a house in Bennett-street
; we slept together, and in the morning I missed these things off the floor; she was still there - I do not know that she had left the room; my clothes were still on the ground; I asked her about it; she said if I did not hold my tongue, she would get somebody to throw me out of the window, and that I should find them when I got a light - I have not found them.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not tell your friends that you had been robbed by three men in the street? A. I did so because I did not like to tell the truth - I was sober - the door was fastened inside.

MARGARET M'DONALD
. I am the wife of
Thomas M'Donald
, and keep this house; the prisoner had lodged with me about a fortnight.
The prisoner put in a written defence, denying the charge, and stating that the door was not fastened, and she had lost her shawl at the same time.

WILLIAM ALLENSBY
. I examined the door, and there was no fastening to it.
NOT GUILTY .

1685.
JAMES RYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August, 21/2lbs. weight of hair, value 7s. 6d. , the goods of
Caleb Welch Collins
, and
Richard Wells
; and
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing it to have been stolen .
MR. PRENDERGAST conducted the prosecution.

CALEB WELCH COLLINS
. I am in partnership with
Richard Wells
; we are horse-hair merchants
, and live in Chancery-lane; Ryan was our porter . In consequence of an anonymous letter I watched him, and about a quarter past nine o'clock, on the 15th of August, I saw the prisoner Jones come in, and when he went out, I followed him, and asked what he had been to the warehouse for; he said he had got a little hair; I asked how much; he seemed confused, and said about a pound or half a pound: I took him into the counting-house, and asked him what he paid for it; he seemed confused, and said Ryan could tell what he paid for it; I called Ryan, who said 18d.: I had the hair weighed, and it was 2lbs. 10ozs., the value of which is 7s. 6d. I told Ryan he must be a very bad man to deliver so much hair at such a price: he said it was a mistake altogether; I said I could not look it over, and got an officer - I had seen nothing take place between the prisoners in the shop; Ryan entreated forgiveness, and said it was his first offence.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Then Jones went into the house? A. Yes; Riley said it was his first offence, and that he had done wrong - I do not recollect his saying it was a mistake - he had lived seventeen years with us, and bore a very good character.

THOMAS WRIGHT WELLS
. I am the son of
Richard Wells
. I went down and asked Ryan how much he had received of Jones; he seemed confused, and said 18d.; after some time he gave it to me - he turned his back; I do not know whether he took it from his jacket pocket; I had seen Jones come in, but saw nothing pass between them - they went into the wareroom together.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you say any thing to Ryan? A. I said, "Why did not you take more than 1s. 6d.?" he said it was the first time.

JONES' Defence. I went to purchase some hair; Ryan asked how much I wanted; I said about half-a-pound; he said, "I am in a hurry," and, looking at this bundle, said, "I dare say this will be half-a-pound; get your money, and I will take it into the counting-house."

RYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined One Year .

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 59.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1686.
HENRY WEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 3 shirts, value 15s. , the goods of
Ephraim Birch
.

EPHRAIM BIRCH
. I am horse-keeper to Mr. Fagg, of Hounslow-heath; I missed my shirts from a little enclosure in the front of my house, on the 22d of August.

ANN HINES
. I washed these shirts, and hung them out on a line opposite the house, about ten minutes before ten o'clock in the morning of the 22d of August; I missed them a little after twelve - I know nothing of the prisoner.

RICHARD PAINTER
. I am a headborough of Stanwell. In consequence of information, I pursued the prisoner, on the 22d of August, between three and four o'clock, and found him lying on the road, about three or four miles from Bedfout; when he got up I found these shirts under him; he begged I would let him go, but did not say how he became possessed of them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought these shirts of a stranger, about one week before I was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

1687.
JOHN WILKIE
and
WILLIAM RICHARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 timepiece, value 2l. , the goods of
Thomas Knight
.

SARAH KNIGHT
. I am the wife of
Thomas Knight
, a cow-keeper , and live in Upper York-street
; this timepiece was on a chest of drawers in the front kitchen; I was in the parlour on the 14th of June, about eleven o'clock in the morning, and saw a boy come up the area steps and run away with something; he was about the size of Wilkie - I ran after him - he got away into some houses in Nelson-place.

JAMES TILLING
. I was in my shop, which is about thirty yards from Knight's, and saw Wilkie run by my door with something under his frock-coat, endeavouring to conceal it - my house is at a corner, leading to Nelson-place; I went to my door, and saw Mrs. Knight - I went to look for Wilkie, but he was gone; I knew him before - I believe he had a white hat on.

DIANA ROBERTS
. I live in Green-street; my husband is a smith. On the 22d of June I took in a parcel from Richards' father - I did not open it; he asked me to take it for him - I gave it up to Field.

WILLIAM FIELD
. This time-piece was brought in a bundle to my house - I do not know who by, as I was not at home - I took it to Knight's.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I am an officer. I received an anonymous letter from Brompton; I went to Knight's, and found they had lost a time-piece. About the 12th of July I took Wilkie, near Maida-hill - he denied the robbery; I took Richards the same day.
NOT GUILTY .

1688.
ABRAHAM LAZARUS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 3 half-crowns, 8 shillings, and 1 sixpence., the monies of
Jeremiah Cockraine
, from the person of
Susannah Cockraine
.

SUSANNAH COCKRAINE
. I am the wife of
Jeremiah Cockraine
, he is a teacher of the classics . On the 26th of July, a little before nine o'clock in the morning, I went to Covent-garden-market
with my little servant girl, who has now left me - I had a small basket in my hand, containing a green silk purse, with 16s. in it. I felt somebody press against me as I went through the market, which was much crowded. I saw the prisoner near me - I came out from the middle of the market, and felt the same pressure again, and then lost my purse - the prisoner was then close to me, and pressing me - it was safe five minutes before; my basket has two small lids; I saw one lid lifted up - I had it in front of me, and the prisoner was before me - I said,"I have lost my purse;" a gentleman took hold of him, and I took hold of his arm at the same time; he was secured instantly, and searched; some money was found on him, but not in my purse - my servant has left me. I saw a hand drawn out of my basket, but cannot say whose it was. I believe I have said it was the prisoners - my deposition was read over to me before I signed it, I think he is the man; I took hold of him, and accused him of it - he denied it; a sovereign, and 16s. 6d. were found on him.

Cross-examined by MR. J. ALLEY . Q. Might he not accidentally push against you? A. I do not know. I saw a hand come from my basket; the prisoner had not time to put the money out of the purse, for he was seized immediately. I did not swear to any of the money - I have my doubts now whether it was him.

WILLIAM DICKINSON
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the office; the prosecutrix positively charged him with the theft - I found a sovereign, fourteen shillings, and a had half-crown, all in his breeches pocket; it was restored him - there was two half-crowns.
MR. COCHRAINE. I think my money was three half crowns, a sixpence, and eight shillings.
NOT GUILTY .

1689.
GEORGE WARD
and
JAMES EDWARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 watch, value 20s. , the goods of
James Whiteman
.

JAMES WHITEMAN
. I am a milkman , and live in Catherine-street, Lisson-grove
. On the 24th of August, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoners together, within a yard of my house - I was a few yards off, talking to a person - I then missed Ward, and saw him come out of my shop - Edwards was sitting down on the step of my door - I am sure they were in company before; my shop door was open - my wife came out after Ward. and said to me, "Why don't you mind the shop, this man was in the parlour;" I then went in and missed the watch from the parlour, which was safe between nine and ten o'clock. I went in pursuit, and took Edwards about one hundred yards off, in two minutes; he had turned a corner; Ward was gone then; he was taken that evening.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you hear your wife say any thing to Ward? A. Yes; she asked what he did there; he said, "He came for a halfpenny worth of milk;" he spoke to Edwards, and they went away - no other person had been in the shop after I saw it safe - Ward had no business in the parlour.
Prisoner EDWARDS. Q. Did I make any resistance? A. No; I can swear to Ward.

SARAH WHITEMAN
. I am the prosecutor's wife; I saw the watch last a little after ten o'clock; I left the shop about two minutes and went into the yard, with some dirty water; I came in again and saw Ward in the parlour; I said, "What do you want?" he said, "A halfpenny worth of milk;" he had a halfpenny in his hand; I said, We had none, and he went out - I walked out and told my husband he had been into the room; nobody else had been there since I had seen the watch - I saw Edwards sitting on the step, and heard Ward say to him, "They have no milk," and both went away together; I went in and missed the watch.

Cross-examined. Q. How far was Ward from where the watch was? A. About a yard or three-quarters; it is a small room; he walked out leasurely. I swear the watch was there at half-past ten o'clock - it did not go, but we had a clock in the room - I did not leave the room till I went into the yard.

THOMAS HOOKER
. I am an officer. I apprehended Ward on the day of the robbery; he denied the charge - the watch has not been found.
Q. Did he not go of his own accord to the office? A Yes; I took him there.

EDWARDS' Defence. They swore before the Magistrate, they had not seen the watch after nine o'clock; then they altered it to ten and eleven - I came by and stopped to tie up my shoe; I went on; he came and saidhe wanted me, on suspicion of stealing the watch; no person had been with me.

WARD -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

1690.
ANN EASTON
and
HANNAH YOWBAND
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 watch, value 8l.; 1 watch-chain, value 25s.; 2 seals, value 10s., and 1 key, value 4s., the goods of
William Ashton
, from his person .

WILLIAM ASHTON
. I am a tailor , and live in St. Martin's-lane. On the 14th of August, about twelve o'clock at night. I was in King-street, Covent-garden
, walking there, looking for a friend of mine, who I had lost - I was rather fresh - I had a watch in my fob, and felt it taken - I called out to the watchman; I believe it was a female who took it; I saw no man - I made a noise to the watchman, and told him I had lost it - I have found it since.
Q. Did you tell the Magistrate the prisoners had been talking to you? A. I did not; for I could not swear to them.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You admit that you had drank a great deal? A. I had been with friends and drank took much. I could not have been long in the street.

Q. How many women had you been drinking with? A. I do not know - nor how many I had been talking to. I have some recollection of crying out of the watchman, and some women were about me. I lost a snuff-box also, and a handkerchief.

JOHN NICHOLLS
. I am shopman to Messrs. Graham and Co., of Tothill-street. I have a seal and key pawned by Easton, in the name of Ann Wilson, about a quarter-past seven o'clock in the morning of the 15th of August.

JOHN ROBINSON JACKSON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tothill-street. I have a chain and seal pawned by Easton, on the 15th of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning.

ROBERT MARKS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tothill-street. I have a gold watch, pawned on the 15th of August, between one and two o'clock in the afternoon, by Easton to the best of my belief.

MICHAEL RAGAN
. I am a watchman. On the 14th of August, I was on duty at the top of King-street, and saw Yowband and another woman running up a turning; the prosecutor came up and said "They have got my watch,""Which?" said I - "Those two women" said he. I ran and took Yowband in Bird-in-hand-court. I brought her back, and he said, "You have got my watch;" she said,"You know what I have got." I said, "If you have got it, give it him;" she then said she had not got it - he gave charge of her, and I took her to the watch-house, She then said she had given it to a woman named Smith, whom I went to take, but could not find. I cannot swear who was the other woman that was with her.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. I suppose the prosecutor was tolerably gone in liquor? A. Yes he was.

ANN HALL
. My husband is a stone-mason. I did not know the prisoners till the morning of Tuesday, between nine and ten o'clock, when Easton came to my place with
Kitty Smith
- they came in and sat down. Smith took from Easton a handkerchief which was warpped up clumsily - she put the handkerchief into my hand, and said it was for me to keep till the middle of the day, I looked at Easton, and said, "There are two of you - I want to know what is in this." I gave it back, and they opened it; there was a watch in it, which looked like this one. They came again, and left a snuff-box and duplicate with me.

JOHN HICKS
. I am a constable. About twelve o'clock at night, on the 14th of August, Yowband was brought into the watch-house; she said she had not the watch, but would tell me where to find it - if I went to No. 5, Viuegar-yard, and searched closely, I should find it, as Kitty Smith had got it. I went and found Smith's husband in bed, but she was not there; next morning, I went to Hall's, in Vine-street, and found this duplicate and a snuff-box.(Property produced and sworn to.)
EASTON'S Defence. I am perfectly innocent. I was not in Yowhand's company - I was in custody at the time the watch was pawned.

EASTON -
GUILTY . Aged 25.

YOUBAND -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Life .

1691.
JOHN FRAUD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 sovereign, 4 half-crowns, and 10 shillings, the monies of
Henry Hawkins
, from his person .

HENRY HAWKINS
. I am a butcher . On the 31st of August, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening, I was rather in liquor - I had about 50s. about me in gold and silver; there were seven or eight shillings; the rest was a sovereign and half-crowns; the prisoner is a coachman - I hired his coach at the top of the Haymarket, and went to King-street - I then got on the box; my money was in my right hand breeches pocket, which was next to him; the coach went on to Bennett-street, Westminster, but it stopped several times before that - I first missed my money when I got off the box - I am positive it was safe when I got on - I then gave him in charge - I had felt him fumbling about me, and told him it would not do - I missed between 40s. and 50s.; he was searched, and two or three sixpences found on him - Sherriff was there part of the time.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Who was the friend you picked up? A. I had no one there; there was a lady there - I said nothing to her; the prisoner said he would take me to his house, to have a fowl dressed, which I had in my pocket - I had bought it in Oxford-street, about nine o'clock - I am not married - I will not swear I was sober - I drove the coach myself part of the way - I did not drive so long as a quarter of an hour; the lady got in near the Horse Guards, and got out in Bennett-street - I did not pay the prisoner - I will not swear that I did not say I had 5l. nor 1l. 12s. 6d.

Q. Had he any opportunity of going to put the money away? A. He went into a public-house; he came in there afterwards for his fare - I went into the public-house to give charge of him - I called the watchman directly, but he did not come directly - I will not say whether the watchman was drunk - I live at No. 7, Earl-street; he drove me to Villiers-street, as I went to see a friend, a butcher - I was in the coach when we were opposite Northumberland-house. there was a friend, of the prisoner's in the coach - I was robbed on the box - I cannot swear whether I was in the coach with his friend.

MARY ANN SHERRIFF
. I was coming down Cockspur-street. The coachman accosted me; the butcher and the other man got out of the coach, and solicited me to get into it - I said I had no objection to a ride - I stepped in, and they all three got on the box together; they drove furiously on through several streets, and when I sat down, I saw the other man had got his hand in the prosecutor's pocket; he took out his money; he and the coachman shared the money between them, behind the prosecutor's back; when I got down I saw the traces of the coach were broken, in consequence of their furious driving.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? I work at the braid trade - I did not know the prosecutor before; it was folly in me to get into the coach: no one was inside with me. I heard the butcher say he had got a fowl in his pocket - I had been taking my work home - I did not hear him say he was robbed of 5l.; he said it was between 2l. and 3l. I live in Bennett-street - I was married fourteen years ago. I dare say I told them I lived in Bennett-street - I do not know whether I did not; the coachman took me imprudently round the waist, and then the other man asked me to go in, and I did; the coachman was tipsy. I do not think he knew what he was about.

COURT. Q. Who drove the coach? A. The butcher first, and then the other man; they drove furiously, and tried to upset the coach - I was in the coach when I saw the other man take the money; it was a charriot - I put out my head, and said, I saw what they had done - the man put out his fist, and said he would put my two eyes into one, and knock me out of the window.

JOSEPH SALT
. I am a japanner, and live in Horseferry-road. I was going down Princes-street, Westminster, and saw the coach stop - I saw a young man get off the box, and run away; the coachman said, "Cut, you b - g - r; cut as quick as possible!" the coachman was at that time off the box; the butcher found he was robbed - I said,"Take his number, and you will find him in the morning;" we went into a public-house; the coachman came in about three quarters of an hour, with two other men; he made a noise, and said, he would punch our heads about if we said he had robbed him; he then pulled out his money, which was only two or three sixpences; but he had been absent three quarters of an hour; the coach was No. 19.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the coachman so drunk as not to know what he was doing? A. He was not sober, but he knew what he was doing; he was drunk.
Mr. PHILLIPS called -

JOHN LITHGO
. I am a watchman, and live in Perkins'-rents, Westminster. I remember seeing the prosecutor on the night in question; he said at first that he had been robbed of 5l. I did not hear him say it was 2l. 10s. - the first word he said was, he had been robbed of 2l. I was calling the hour, and then went up to the coachman, and said he was my prisoner; the prosecutor then said, "You scoundrel, you have robbed me of 5l.; take charge of him." I said I could not take him from his horses; the prosecutor then said he was robbed of 35s.; he was in liquor, but knew what he was doing. I looked at the coach minutely; no trace was broken - I know Sherriff to be a common prostitute in Bennett-street; this is my beat - I have seen her there with men, like other prostitutes.

MARY ANN SHERRIFF
re-examined. I have lived three years at Mrs. Smith's, No. 10. Little George-street, Hampstead-road, and was there till last Saturday fortnight. I have lived at No. 4, Bennett-street, only for the last three weeks, and have never been out after ten o'clock at night - I am not in the habit of getting into coaches - I thought no harm of going in this coach. I had been carrying home a large bundle - I never got my living as a prostitute, or picked up men in the street. I am to return to Mrs. Smith's next Saturday, or to No. 10, Bowling-green-lane.

JOSEPH SALT
. I have been to this woman's house, and always found her hard at work at her needle.
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Transported for Seven Years .

1692.
GEORGE YOUNG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 2 silver tea-spoons, value 8s. , the goods of
Collingwood Marshall
.
The prisoner pleaded GUILTY. Aged 51.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1693.
ELIZA EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 key, value 2d.; 1 tobacco-stopper, value 6d., and 3 shillings, the property of
John Bex
, from his person .

JOHN BEX
. I am a collar-maker . On the 1st of September, between nine and eleven o'clock in the day time, I met the prisoner and another woman in the street; we went to a public-house, and had some liquor and some coffee. I was not quite sober; I laid my head on the table, and went to sleep. I awoke in about an hour, and the prisoner was then gone; I missed my handkerchief out of my hat; also a key, a tobacco-stopper, and 3s., from my pocket. I saw the prisoner again on the 3d of September, in Tottenham-court-road, with the handkerchief round her neck; it has not my name on it, but I knew it by this mark, which had been made in my presence.

Prisoner. I met this man with another woman; we went to a public-house at the corner of Charles-street, and had five half-pints of gin between three of us. I was perfectly sober, but the other woman was very sick, and she went out; he lent her that blue handkerchief to wipe her face with - we then went to another house, and when I got out I found the handkerchief in my hand, but I was in liquor before I parted with him - he went to the bar to change a sovereign, but the landlady said he had got silver in his hand.

THOMAS SIMONS
. I am a watchman. I took up the prisoner on the 3d of September, and found this handkerchief about her neck.

JOHN BEX
. I did go to change a sovereign, and the landlady could not give me change; she said she had seen some silver in my hand - there had been no one in the room but us two. I had my handkerchief in my hat, by my side, on the table.
NOT GUILTY .

1694.
JOHN OSBORN
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 13th of July , 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Edward Palmer
, the elder , from the person of
Edward Palmer
, the younger
.

MARY PALMER
. I am the wife of
Edward Palmer
; we live at No. 6, Long's-court, Leicester-square. On the 13th of July I was out with my son, Edward, in my arms. I felt the child go back in my arms - I turned round and saw the prisoner with the necklace in his hand - he was putting it into his trousers; he ran off - I gave an alarm, and followed - a gentleman stopped him, but he had not then got it; he had turned a corner. I am quite certain he had had it.
Prisoner's Defence. I had not seen it.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

1695.
HENRY BARRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 fixture, that is to say, 1 iron stove, value 10s., the goods of
John Serancke
, and fixed to a building belonging to him, against the statute .

ISABELLA HEFFER
. Mr. Serancke left the key of the house, No. 5, Euston-crescent
, with my sister, who was to show it. On the 17th of July the prisoner came and asked to look at it. I went and showed it him - he was very particular in going round, and said he would call in the morning upon Mr. Serancke; he went away, and said no more; when he left I pulled the door to and locked it; this was about eight o'clock in the morning - the parlour stove was then safe, and the copper in the back kitchen. I locked the parlour door, but left the key on the outside.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you know any thing of this man? A. No, but I am sure he is the man.

LUCY BAKER
. I live at No. 4, Euston-crescent. My little boy told me the next morning, between nine and ten o'clock, that a man had gone out with this stove - I looked out, and saw the prisoner with it. I gave no alarm, as I thought it might be quite right. I afterwards heard the door shut again - I looked up, and saw the prisoner with some covings on his shoulder - I then sent to the person who had the key, to know if any person had fetched the key away; Miss Heffer came, and said she could not open the door, there must be some one inside. I went to the door, and sent my boy for a constable; and while he was gone the prisoner came out with this other stove.
Cross-examined. Q. Then he was taken? A. Yes, he passed our house, and was taken.

JOHN HEFFER
. I was set to watch the premises by Mrs. Baker. I saw the prisoner open the door with a latch-key - I saw him come out with a stove on his shoulder - I followed him up Curzon-street, and he was stopped with it.

CHARLES JOHNSON
. I am a constable. I was sent for, and in going towards the house I met the prisoner with this stove. I stopped him - in going back, he said he was bringing it from his own house in Seymour-street; when we got to Euston-crescent we met the boy, who said he was the man who brought it out of the house - the prisoner then said he was employed by Mr. Sabine - I took him there, and heard from Mr. Sabine's clerk that he had no authority to go there; he ran from me, but I caught him again - I found some keys on him, one of which fits the latch of the door, and one fits the parlour door.

CHARLES SABINE
. I am an attorney, and agent to Mr.
John Serancke
. This house was in my care, and I had the letting of it for him - I know the prisoner, but had not employed him. I had been over the house a few days before.
Cross-examined. Q. You say you knew him? A. Yes, I had employed him to repair the house about two years ago.

GEORGE DICKINSON
. I am clerk to Mr. Sabine. I went to the house and missed a stove from the parlour, and one from the front room first floor.
Prisoner. I wish to throw myself on the mercy of the Court; my children were in want of bread. I was formerly in business, but have been greatly reduced.
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Confined Three Months .

1696.
THOMAS RICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 watch, value 3l., and 1 watch-key, value 6d., the goods of
Joseph Copping
, from his person .

JOSEPH COPPING
. On the 1st of September, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was going along Whitechapel
, when the prisoner came and snatched my watch and seal from my fob; he ran off - I followed, and never lost sight of him till I took him with them in his hand.

THOMAS YEARLEY
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and saw the prisoner running across the road - he made his way towards Goulston-street - he was brought back, and I took hold of him; Copping came up, and said, "That is the man that took my watch;" the prisoner had no watch then, but Copping said he had taken the watch from him before - that he got from him again, and I took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and this man came and took me - Copping said I was the man, but I never saw the watch.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

1697.
MARTHA SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 watch, value 30s.; 1 watch-chain, value 7s.; 1 seal, value 5s.; 1 watch-key, value 2s.; 1 half-sovereign, and 2l. 5s., in monies numbered, the property of
Samson Maynard
, from his person .

SAMSON MAYNARD
. I am a cow-keeper . I was at a public-house in Fleet-market; I left my horse and cart at the door, and went into the house; the prisoner came in while I was there - I had seen her twice before: we drank together. She then got up into the cart with me, and she drove the cart away - she took me up Holborn-hill, to the Wheatsheaf, public-house, and gave me something to drink- she then took me to a bad house; I recollect going up stairs, and sitting on a bed; I was very sick, and she took hold of my head, and said, "My dear, I will hold your head;" she then got her hand into my pocket - I said,"Don't rob me;" she said No, but she took out my money and my watch, by force. I then got on the bed, and the lady of the house came up, and called the patrol; she said she should be searched. I found some of my money on the drawers in the morning, but I lost 45s.

WILLIAM RICHARDSON
. I am a patrol of St. Ann's parish. I went to the house between seven and eight o'clock, on the 20th of August - I found the prosecutor very tipsy: I asked the prisoner if she had any property to give it to me - she would not, because she said she did not know whatI was. I then searched her, and took from her a watch and some money - I had been on duty before, and saw her and the prosecutor going along in the cart: I followed them, and told the woman of the house that the cart must go to the Green-yard, if the man did not come and take it away.

SARAH CURTIS
. I live at No. 2, Pheasant-buildings, Gray's Inn-lane. The prisoner and the prosecutor came there, and had a room in my mistress' house; the prisoner called me, and said her friend was very sick and ill, and asked me to get a little brandy for him, and she gave me half-a-crown; my mistress then said she should not go away without the prosecutor, and sent me for the patrol, and insisted on her being searched. The watch was found in her possession - she said she was going home to his wife.

HANNAH CODD
. I keep this house. The prisoner was going down - I said she should not go without the man; I went and shook him, and asked if he had a watch about him - he was not sensible, but he said at last he had bought a watch for 2l. that day.

JOHN BLAKE
. I took the prisoner the next morning; I found a bit of a broken watch-glass on her.(Watch produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner. When the patrol came up stairs I would not give it up, because I did not know what authority he had; I said I was as well able to keep it as he was - he then took it from me, and the prosecutor told him to call in the morning.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I met him at this public-house, and, knowing him, went in the cart with him; when we got to Gray's Inn-lane, he had more drink, and made me almost tipsy; he gave me the money to take care of, and take to his wife; a man said the cart would be taken to the Green-yard, and I went in search of the cart; he, missing me, asked for his property, and the landlady gave me in custody.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1698.
WILLIAM ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 6 yards of printed cotton, value 13s., and 1 shawl, value 25s. , the goods of
James Lynch
.

CATHERINE LYNCH
. I am the wife of
James Lynch
, a porter - we live in Oxford-buildings, Oxford-street
. The prisoner lodged in my house on the 11th of August - he slept there on the Friday night, and on the Saturday night I left him to mind my room while I went out to buy a cap; when I returned in a quarter of an hour my little child, whom I had left at home, was crying - the prisoner had broken a lock, and taken my shawl, which he had in his hand - I said, "What are you doing?" he said nothing. I laid hold of the shawl, but he got away, and I could not hold him; my neighbours were in bed - my husband came home soon after: he went after the prisoner all night, but could not find him; we then offered a reward. I afterwards missed the cotton - I have never seen the property since.
Prisoner. Q. Can you stand before the Judge, and say you saw me with the shawl? A. Yes, and you said you would knock me down if I stopped you.

JAMES LYNCH
. I am the husband of the last witness. - I came home about ten o'clock, and heard what had happened; the prisoner and the property were then gone - he was taken on the 19th of August, but nothing was found on him: he was in a lodging-house, with his arm round a girl's neck; he said to me, "I don't know you;" I said,"Don't you know where you lodged?" he said, "Oh! I know you now."

ROBERT TURNER
. I took the prisoner - he denied all knowledge of the property.
Prisoner's Defence. I did lodge in the house one night. I heard an uproar in the street, and went out to see; I did not come back that night, that is the truth - they keep a very bad bawdy-house.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined One Month .

1699.
JOHN BRYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 5 putlogs, value 2s., the goods of
James Hart
; and 1 piece of board, value 2d. , the goods of
Samuel Lewis Hart
.

JAMES HART
. I am the sub-contractor at the London Docks
; one of these putlogs are mine, and the others I had borrowed - the prisoner had worked there, but had left, being unwell - I went to his house with the officer - I called out at the door, "Bryan, have you any thing of mine?" a voice within said, "Nothing;" things were sometimes left at his house, which was the reason of my asking - I went behind the house, and saw this putlog thrown out of a window, and the officer produced another.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was the prisoner in bed? A. No; he was unwell - he had the care of several of these things - I desired one Riley to take some rammers to his house, but no putlogs - I think it was done by somebody else; I should be proud to employ him again.

JOHN STEPTOE
. I am a bricklayer. I was at work at the docks, and missed a putlog, which I think I had seen on the scaffold the day before.

JAMES JEFFRIES
. I am a constable. I found this putlog under his bed; he bore a very good character.
NOT GUILTY .

1700.
JOHN BARNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 2 sovereigns, and 1 sixpence , the monies of
Zackariah Brewster
.

MARY ANN BREWSTER
. I am the wife of
Zackariah Brewster
, a warehouseman - we live in the Curtain-road
, where I keep a milliner's shop. On the 28th of July, about eleven o'clock, I saw my two sovereigns and a sixpence safe in a piece of paper, in the till - I was in the back parlour at half-past twelve o'clock, and heard the lock of the till go - I turned and saw the prisoner with his arms across the counter - I asked what he wanted; he said, "A ready made shirt;" I said, "I keep no such things;" he went out - I looked at the till and missed the money - I ran out caught him, and asked him for the money - he said, he knew nothing about it; I have not found it.

JOSEPH BIRCH
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner - he said he went in to buy a shirt - he had no money about him, and I said he had no money to pay for it; he said if there had been one to suit him, he should call for it in the evening.

Prisoner's Defence. I went in and knocked on the counter; she said she did not sell shirts - she came out and took me, about two yards off - she went back and took out six or seven sovereigns - she said, "These are not what I want;" there were two in a paper.
MRS. BREWSTER. There were four other sovereigns in another part of the till - I had not been out of the shop a quarter of an hour.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1701.
ELIZABETH BOYLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 pelisse, value 20s. , the goods of
Edward Baylis
.

GEORGE MELLISH GRAHAM
. I am servant to
Edward Baylis
, pawnbroker , of Hampstead-road. The prisoner came in to pawn an article on the 7th of August, but refused to take what was offered her; I was folding up some goods, and had a pelisse laying there - I was called away for a moment, and on returning, she was gone and the pelisse also; I sent a lad after her, but he could not find her; she came again in the afternoon, with the article, and said she would take the money we had offered her: I said we had lost a pelisse: she said if I thought she had it, I had better take her; in the evening Stack brought the pelisse to pawn, and said where she got it: I went with her, and found the prisoner in bed - she was taken.

MARGARET STACK
. The prisoner gave me the pelisse to pawn.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence (written.) I went to the shop to pawn a coat - I was in liquor, and when I got home with it, I found this pelisse in it, which I was ignorant of.

GEORGE M. GRAHAM
. She did not appear in liquor - she frequented our shop; she said it had been folded up with the coat.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Two Months .

1702.
DANIEL CORCORAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 1 shawl, value 1s., and 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
Levy Hart
.

LEVY HART
. I am a salesman , and live in Monmouth-street
. On the 9th of August, about nine o'clock at night, the prisoner, three other men, and a woman, came into my shop, and looked at some hats; while I was looking for one, they pushed down a horse with clothes on it, and while I was picking it up, the prisoner went out with the shawl; I followed, and collared him three yards off, and took it from him - the boots were wrapped up in it - he had taken them off the counter.

TIMOTHY RYAN
. I took him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went with two soldiers to buy a hat; one of them was tipsy, and went against the horse, which fell down; I declare I never saw the things till I got to the office.
GUILTY . Aged 51.
Confined Two Months .

1703.
JOHN EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 1 ham, value 3s. , the goods of
Charles Docker
.

HENRY COOKE
. I am shopman to
Charles Docker
, cheesemonger , of Great Chapel-street, Westminster
. I was at tea on the 20th of July; Norris came in, and said a man had got a ham; I went and saw the prisoner at the counter, with something in his apron; I asked what he had there: he said, nothing: I put my hand under his apron, and this ham fell on the floor.

JOHN NORRIS
. I am shopman to Mr. Docker; the prisoner came in, and asked for a rasher of bacon, and while I turned he took the ham.

JOHN SIMPSON
. I was sent for, and took him; he had no money whatever.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he was intoxicated, and did not know that he had the ham, and pleading distress.
GUILTY. Aged 38.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1704.
THOMAS FRANCIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 5 live tame fowls, price 9s. , the property of
Edward Thomas Rogers
.

EDWARD THOMAS ROGERS
. These fowls are not mine, but my brother's.
NOT GUILTY .

1705.
RICHARD HOWARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 cheese, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Henry Bonsor
.

HENRY BONSOR
. I am a cheesemonger , and live at Shadwell
. I was sitting in my back room, and saw three men pass my window twice, and look in: I heard a noise the second time, like something being drawn off the board; I ran out and missed the cheese; I went into the street, and saw the prisoner running down the turning with something under his arm; I called Stop thief! and he dropped the cheese - he was secured, without my losing sight of him.

ROBERT JEFFREY
. I received him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Two Months .

1706.
GEORGE HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing on the 7th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 5s. , the goods of
John Manley Gerrish
.

ELIZA GERRISH
. I am the wife of
John Manley Gerrish
. On the 7th of August I had this handkerchief to wash for a gentleman; I missed it about two o'clock in the afternoon, from the end of a table in my room: I had seen it a few minutes before - the prisoner had brought some bread to my house that day; I went up stairs, and when I returned he stood with his back to the table.

JOHN MANLEY GERRISH
. I went next morning with an officer to a house, and found the prisoner in bed with a young woman; I told him about the handkerchief; he asked if I had any children to take it away; I told him No, and he had better give it up, as my wife would lose the family washing: I then gave charge of him, and, as we went along, he said it was pawned, and he had thrown away the duplicate, but the officer found it on the witness.

EDMUND GROVER
. On the morning the prisoner of him; I taken, I bought the duplicate of a handkerchief of him; I sent my wife to the pawnbroker's, and she brought back this handkerchief; I put it on my neck; the officer and Mr. Gerrish came and claimed it.

RICHARD CONSTANTINE
. I am an officer, and apprehended the prisoner; he at first said he had not taken it; we then went to a public-house; some people there said to him, "Why don't you tell the truth? the poor woman will lose her washing:" he then took me to the pawnbroker, who said he was the man who pawned it; he then told me who he had sold the duplicate to.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1707.
THOMAS JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 saddle, value 10s.; 1 bridle, value 5s.; 1 pair of overalls, value 10s., and 1 pair of kneecaps, value 5s. , the goods of
George Johnson
.

GEORGE JOHNSON
. I live at the turnpike office, Bromley
; I found my shed broken open, and missed this property - I know nothing of the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOSEPH SEARCH
. I am a watchman. On the 30th of August, between two and three o'clock in the morning, I went to Mr. Johnson's stable, to look for some bad characters, and found the prisoner sitting in the shed; he had the stirrups, leather, and bridle in his pocket; the other things were packed up, near to where he was sitting: he said he came there to sleep - the harness room was broken open.

THOMAS BARFORD
. I am a constable, and received the prisoner in charge. I found on him a screw-driver, which I compared with some marks on the harness room door - it fits them exactly.

JOSEPH LEWELL
. I am in the employ of Mr. George Johnson; I locked all this property up safe at night.
GUILTY . Aged 70.
Confined One Month .

1708.
MARY ANN KENNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 7 yards of printed cotton, value 7s., the goods of
Robert Robertson
; and a veil, value 10s. , the goods of
Caroline Jane Monk
.

CAROLINE JANE MONK
. I am chambermaid to
Robert Robertson
, of Oxendon-street
. On the 17th of July, the prisoner, who had been my housemaid , left the service, and about an hour after she was gone, I missed fifteen sovereigns from my box; I went with an officer to her lodgings; a white veil of mine was found in her bonnet-box next day - the cotton was found in her room; I had missed the veil three weeks before.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What kind of a house is this? A. A house of accommodation; I believe it is called a brothel; master does not make presents to the servants; a glass was once missed, and it was found under the bed.

JAMES COLLINS
. I am an upholsterer; I was at work at this house, and went in search of the prisoner - I went to her lodgings with the officer, and broke her box open.

JOSEPH MEDCALF
. I am an officer. I went to her room, and found this curtain in a box; I afterwards found the veil in the bonnet-box, which she said was her sister's.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not her sister taken up? A. Yes, but she was discharged.

COURT. Q. Where was the bonnet-box? A. That was pointed out to me by another person next day - it was in the room the night before, but I did not open it; she said both boxes were her sister's at first.

JAMES COLLINS
. I can swear to this cotton - it was missing from a bed which I was putting up there - we sent to the callenderer's for it, thinking it had not come home.

CAROLINE JANE MONK
re-examined. I do not hire the servants - I manage the house; the prisoner left without giving warning - she had been five or six weeks with us.
GUILTY. Aged 27.
Of stealing the cotton only .

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1709.
JOHN LANCASTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 jacket, value 2s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2d., and 1 cap, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Barker
.

THOMAS BARKER
. I am servant to Mr. Elliott , of Finsbury-pavement
. On the 29th of July I put my things into the coach-house about half-past ten o'clock, and missed them in about an hour.

BENJAMIN BISHOP
. I lived at the same place with Barker. I saw the prisoner go into the coach-house, and come out with these things - the cap was on his head; he saw me, and threw them into a gig in the yard; we wanted him to go about his business, but he would not. I took the cap from him, and gave him in charge, because he would not go away. I saw him take the jacket from his hat.
Prisoner's Defence. I went down the yard to the privy - they perceived me; they took my hat off, and I would not go away without it - they did not want me but my hat.
NOT GUILTY .

1710.
JAMES RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 pair of breeches, value 20s.; 9 waistcoats, value 12s.; 8 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; 10 pairs of stockings, value 8s.; 2 pencil-cases, value 2s., and 3 caps, value 2s. , the goods of
George Crowfoot
.

GEORGE CROWFOOT
. I am a groom . I lodged at the Dolphin public-house, in Oxford-street
- I had been into the country about seven weeks. I left my box locked, and took the key with me; when I returned I found it still locked, but nothing in it; the prisoner lodged at the house - five pairs of stockings, and a night cap were found on him.

GEORGE BALL
. I keep the Dolphin. I had the prisoner secured, and asked how he came to take the things away; he said he had taken nothing but the stockings, and they were found in his room - he said at the office that he had worn them, but he did not say so then.

ELIZABETH REX
. I am a laundress. On the 15th of August the prisoner brought me two shirts, four handkerchiefs, and six pairs of stockings to wash - Crowfoot claimed three pairs of the stockings. I delivered them to Mrs. Ball.

WILLIAM KIMBERLEY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found a pair of stockings in his hat - he said he had worn them - some others were found in his room.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Twelve or fourteen people lodged in the house. I thought these stockings were my own - they were laying about.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

1711.
JOHN TOMLINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 30 penny-pieces, and 60 halfpence , the monies of
Charles Richardson
.

CHARLES RICHARDSON
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Whitecross-street. On the 14th of July, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, the prisoner came into my shop, and tasted some bacon and cheese, but bought none - another person came in, which took my attention;the prisoner went down the shop, round the counter, went up to my desk, on which was 5s. in copper - he went out. I went after him, and as I took hold of him, he dropped the paper of copper - I find he bears a most excellent character.

GEORGE GARRETT
. I am a watchman. I saw Richardson stop the prisoner, and the paper of copper fell from him.

CHARLES GAMBLE
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house - I found 9d. on him.
The prisoner stated that he had committed the offence under the influence of intoxication.
GUILTY. Aged 34.

Strongly recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

1712.
ANN MOSELEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July
, 2 sheets, value 6s.; 1 frock, value 2s.; 2 blankets, value 2s.; 1 cloth, value 1s.; 4 napkins, value 2s.; 2 pockets, value 6d.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; 2 remnants of lace, value 2s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 bottle, value 1s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 3d., and 1 cap, value 3d. , the goods of
Daniel Gardiner
; and
MARY SPAREY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen, against the statute .

DANIEL GARDINER
. I am a brush-maker , and live in Spitalfields
- Mosely was nurse in my family, from Easter to July, when she left to go to see her friends - I missed the table-cloth from my bed-room drawer the night she left - a dirty one had been put in its place; next day I found the drawers were stripped of my wife's wearing apparel - the articles stated were gone among others. I got a search-warrant; we found Mosely at work, at a house in Rosemary-lane, where she had gone from my house - the officer searched her, and found some duplicates on her - we went in a coach to her lodgings; we found Sparey sitting there; she said something to her - the officer found a quantity of things there; they have my wife's name on them; my wife died a few days after this, it gave her such a turn when she heard of it - she had been ill for some time. Sparey had called to see Moseley when she was at my house.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Did not you at first find Sparey in the room, and make her tell you where Moseley was? A. Yes; the officer said he had a search-warrant; they told us where most of the things were. I have been robbed by my nephew.

THOMAS VANN
. I am an officer, and took Moseley - as we were in the coach, I saw her put her hand into her pocket; I said, "I must search first." I found some duplicates on her - she then begged Mr. Gardiner's pardon; we found Sparey at the lodgings. I said I had a warrant, and they had better give up the things, which she did - Sparey said, "Moseley had brought them, and told her the sheets would do to shift her bed;" she seemed near her confinement - Moseley said Sparey knew nothing of it.

EDWARD RUBY
. I am a pawnbroker, of Whitechapel: I have a sheet, shirt, and handkerchief, pawned by Moseley for 7s., and a tea-spoon, for 1s. 6d., in the name of Mary Gorby.

JOHN YOWART
. I am a pawnbroker, and have a tablecloth, pawned by Moseley.

MOSELEY's Defence. The things I took to Sparey's I had bought for her. I had pawned the other articles for Mrs. Gardiner, who was a very drunken woman, and lived on brandy, rum and gin, all the time I was there.

DANIEL GARDINER
. My wife was deranged for twelve months; the prisoner had the care of her.

MOSELEY -
GUILTY . Aged 57.
Confined One Month .

SPAREY -
NOT GUILTY .

1713.
WILLIAM TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 1 rug, value 7s. , the goods of
William Cowen
.

SOPHIA COWEN
. I am the wife of
William Cowen
, a broker - we live in Clerkenwell
; this rug was stolen from a chair in our shop, about half-past eleven o'clock in the morning.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I was in Compton-street; the prisoner passed me with the rug: I followed him, and he dropped it - I laid hold of him; he said it was his first offence, and if I would forgive him, he would not do so again; I did not lose sight of him.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.
GUILTY. Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1714.
ESTHER BRANSOM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 1 shawl, value 4s.; 1 clock, value 6s., and 1 frock, value 2s. , the goods of
Abraham Cooper
, her master .

MARIA COOPER
. I am the wife of
Abraham Cooper
; the prisoner was in our service on the 9th of August, and on the 10th I gave her in charge; she said nothing to me - she said she had lent the articles to her brother, to keep him dry, as it rained hard, but that was not stated to me - she was a year and eight months with us.

WALTER LEY
. I am an officer. I produce a cloak and shawl, which I got from the prisoner's brother - I found the prisoner in the watch-house; she said she lent the cloak and shawl to her brother, and he had pawned the other articles, which she had given him.

JOHN BRANSOM
. I am the prisoner's brother; she gave me the shawl and cloak - I had been out of work, and asked her for 4s. - she said she had no money, but would give me a cloak and whittle of her own, which I pawned for 4s.

WILLIAM ROBERTS
. I am a pawnbroker, and have a frock and some patchwork, pawned in the name of Bransom - I do not know who by.

WILLIAM CLUNES
. I am a pawnbroker; the prisoner's brother pawned this cloak and shawl with me - they were redeemed again before I heard of this.

JOHN HUTT
. I took the prisoner into custody; she said she lent her brother the cloak and shawl one wet night; her brother brought them to the watch-house.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I lent him them for a week.
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Strongly recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .

1715.
FRANCES CARTWRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 12 pairs of socks, value 1s. 6d., and 24 yards of calico, value 11s. , the goods of
William Jones
, her master .

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a linen-draper and live in Tottenham-court-road. The prisoner was in my service about six weeks; I missed this property from my warehouse - I received information and found them in her box; which the housekeeper pointed out; it was not locked.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did she not deny all knowledge of the socks? A. At first she did; I sent for the officer, she then seemed to show great contrition; and said she hoped I would forgive her.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer, and took her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

1716.
OSBORN PANTON
was indicted for
embezzlement .

ROBERT STONE
. I am a job-master and live in High-street, Mary-le-bone
; the prisoner was my clerk at a wharf
which I have at Milbank-street, Westminster; it was his busines to take orders and receive money, which he was to account for to Mr. Jeffries daily.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long had he lived with you? A. Twelve months; I am a coal and corn dealer at that wharf.

THOMAS MARTIN
. I live in Osnaburg-street, and deal with Mr. Stone. On the 12th of April I paid the prisoner a cheque for 31l. 6s., on Sir
Claude Scott
, on Stone's account - here is his receipt for it.

JOHN LLOYD
. I am clerk at Sir
Claude Scotts
. On the 12th of April, I cashed this cheque on account of Mr. Martin - I gave five 5l notes, six sovereigns, and the rest in silver.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know you paid it? A. By a mark on the cheque, and the entry in the book.

JOSEPH JEFFRIES
. I am in the employ of Mr. Stone - the prisoner used to bring me the cash, just as he received it - he never accounted to me for any money received from Mr. Martin; he paid me nothing that day - and never accounted for this.
Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I conduct Mr. Stone's business, as a friend; I receive no salary - I have no part of the profits - it was his duty to bring me the cheque or the money.
COURT. Q. There would have been nothing said if he got it cashed, and brought you the money? A. No.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1717.
WILLIAM SMART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 2 deal boards, value 9s. , the goods of
Samuel Beaumont Cheeswright
, his master .

SAMUEL BEAUMONT CHEESWRIGHT
. I am a timber merchant , and live in Kingsland-road - the prisoner was my sawyer , and had no authority to take boards from my yard.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you authorize me to take out a plank that day? A. No; I left word for the carman to take it - but these are deals; the prisoner absconded next day - there was 5s. or 6s. due to him; when he was taken he said he took the deals out of the canal, but they were dry.

EBENEZA CHEESWRIGHT
. On the 1st of August I saw the prisoner take a deal out of my father's yard, about eleven o'clock in the morning; and in the evening I saw him down the yard, tipsy, and in a few minutes he went down to the canal - I saw him afterwards with another deal on his shoulder; he had taken it through a place in the pales - I ran and told him to bring it back; he said he would not - for Mr. Barlow had told him to take it.

MARY DOLTON
. I am servant to the prosecutor and saw the prisoner take a six feet deal, out about eleven o'clock in the morning; and in the evening I saw him crossing the bridge with another.

HENRY RAY
. I am carman to the prosecutor; his son called me in the evening to go after the prisoner - but he was gone.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am an officer. I went to the prosecutor's yard, and found an opening, through which a deal appeared to have been drawn.
Prisoner's Defence. I took none but what I was sent with by Mr. Cheeswright.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Six Weeks .

1718.
JOHN BURY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 2lbs. of yarn, value 3s. , the goods of
Henry Keat
and
Ebeneza Keat
.

EBENEZA KEAT
. I am in partnership with
Henry Keat
, my father; we are rug manufacturers
. On the 5th of September, between six and seven o'clock in the morning, I was called up - and waited outside, till the prisoner came out of the premises - I took his hat off, and found this yarn in it; he had once worked for us.

JOHN NASH
. I am in Mrssrs. Keats' employ; the prisoner came there, and I saw him take the yarn - I gave information.
GUILTY. Aged 41.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

1719.
JAMES BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th July , I live tame fowl, price 18d., and 1 dead fowl, value 18d. , the property of
Thomas Perry
.

THOMAS PERRY
. I keep the Water Works, public-house , Belgrave-place. On the 8th of August, at six o'clock in the morning, I fed my fowls, and they were all right - in the afternoon I missed one. I went on the wharf and saw a quantity of feathers; I had missed another a few days before.

JOHN SOUTHERWOOD
. I am an officer. I found this fowl at the prisoner's house, in a small lane, near Chelseacommon - and I found him on the wharf, with a dead fowl in a bag, which I saw him take up; it was quite warm - he said he found it.

THOMAS PERRY
. The dead fowl is the one I lost that day - I missed the live one some days before.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the dead one on the wharf; I did not know the live one was at my house.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Two Months .

1720.
JAMES BOTTOMY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 till, value 1s.; 1 shilling, 12 sixpences, and the sum of 6s. 31/2d. in copper monies , the property of
James Ayres
.

JAMES AYRES
. I keep a baker's shop in Goldsmith's-row, Hackney-road
. On the 15th of August I was in thebake-house - my mother called me, and said the till was gone - I ran out, and found it in the middle of the field, about a quarter of a mile from my house. I picked up some money by it.

MARY BYERS
. Between one and two o'clock, I was in my son's passage, and saw the prisoner in the shop, reaching over the counter - I asked what he wanted, he turned round and ran out. I saw him running very fast - I did not see the till in his hand - I am quite certain of his person - Mrs. Smith came up.

SUSANNAH SARAH SMITH
. I saw the prisoner come out of the shop with the till in his hand - he ran very fast towards the field - I ran out and followed him. I saw him throw the till down in the middle of the field - he then ran very fast, but I saw him caught, and am certain he is the man - I lost sight of him for a moment.

JOHN MARTIN
. I took the prisoner in the middle of Clement's field - I did not see the till.

THOMAS FRANKLIN
. I am an officer, and took him in custody.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going home, and saw several people running - I ran, and was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1721.
WILLIAM BAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of July , 1 pair of boots, value 4s. , the goods of
Walker Brewster
.

WALKER BREWSTER
. I am a perfumer . On the 23d of July I missed these boots from my kitchen - the prisoner was in my employ, and had to clean them - he said he knew nothing of them.

JAMES WALLIS
. I am a pawnbroker, and have a pair of boots pawned in the name of John Baker - I cannot say who by.

JOSEPH COLLINS
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner - he said he had pawned the boots, that the duplicate was at his mother's lodgings, in a box, and he meant to redeem them. GUILTY. Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Whipped and Discharged.

1722.
JOHN FUZZEY
and
JOHN DAVIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 15 planes, value 30s.; 2 saws, value 2s.; 2 squares, value 3s.; 1 pair of compasses, value 6d., and 4 chisels, value 4s., the goods of
Robert Malom
; 2 planes, value 7s.; 1 pair of compasses, value 6d.; 2 chisels, value 6d.; 1 screw-driver, value 6d., and 1 square, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Lincoln
.

ROBERT MALOM
. I am a carpenter , and was working at Belvoir-terrace, Bridge-road, Vauxhall
. On Saturday night, the 11th of August, I left my tools all safe, and on Monday morning, I was going to work, I found the back kitchen window broken open, and all my tools from a box, and under the bench gone. I missed those stated in the indictment. I went to Mr. Graham, the pawnbroker, in Tothill-street, to give information, and as I came out of there I met Fuzzey coming in with a basket of tools - I let him go in, and then claimed them - they were part of mine.

THOMAS LINCOLN
. I lost some tools in another house in the same terrace.

THOMAS PACE
. I am an officer. On the morning of the 13th I was fetched to Mr. Harris's, a pawnbroker, and found Davis there, offering tools in pawn - he said they were his own. I searched him, and found a pair of compasses in his pocket - Malom claimed them.

BENJAMIN TIMBRELL
. I took Fuzzey in charge with the tools. I found two squares on him at the watch-house.(Property produced and sworn to.)

FUZZEY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

DAVIS -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1723.
MARY HURLEY
and
ANN DAVIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 2 pieces of printed cotton, containing 21 yards, value 1l. , the goods of
Sarah Dyson
and
Mary Dyson
.

SARAH DYSON
. I am in partnership with my sister
Mary - we have a linen-draper's shop
, in Margaret-street, Hackney-fields
. On the 8th of September the prisoners came to purchase some print - we showed them several - none suited - they bought none; and as soon as they left, I missed a piece of cotton. I ran out, but not seeing them, came in again, and my sister said something. I then missed another piece, and ran out again and passed a street, and in returning met them coming out of that street. I told them I missed two prints; they said they would go back if I made no alarm, and as I got to the door, I stopped to call a neighbour - they got a little before me into the shop. I went in and saw the green-print go from Hurley's hand on the counter - the other piece was then on the counter.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. They gave you a good deal of trouble, did not they? A. Yes; there were several prints on the counter. I did not miss the green pieces first - one of them had a basket, I think it was Hurley - they offered to be searched afterwards; neither of them had a green shawl on, that I observed.

MARY DYSON
. My sister called me into the shop; she ran out, and I missed the green print; she ran in again - I said the green print was also gone; she ran out, and brought them back, and I saw the green print in the basket, before it was thrown on the counter; and, soon after, I saw both pieces on the counter; Hurley then said,"Search me;" I said, "There is no occasion to search you, you have thrown enough out of your basket;" she said, "Will you swear a person's life away in that manner! Oh! what lies."
Cross-examined. Q. Had one of them a green shawl on? A. Yes; I am sure the prints were not on the counter a few minutes before.

MARY HIGHLAND
. My husband is a presser. I saw the prisoners in Margaret-street - Davis took something out of her pocket hole, and put into the basket; she then took something else more bulky, which appeared to be the green print, and put in - they carried the basket between them.
Cross-examined. Q. What time was this? A. Between three and four o'clock; I never saw them before.

THOMAS FRANKLIN
. I am a constable. I received them in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

HURLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Three Months .

DAVIS -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1724.
JULIA HASWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 3 blankets, value 3s.; 2 pillows, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 1 pair of snuffers, value 3d., and 1 snuffer-tray, value 3d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Chorley
.

ELIZABETH CHORLEY
. I am a widow , and live in Grove-place, Bethnal-green
. On the 3d of July I let the prisoner a furnished room; on the 18th I went into the room, and asked for the loan of a pillow - she hesitated; I thought all was not right; I sent for an officer, and called her into the parlour; we went up and missed these articles - the duplicates of them were found in a cupboard in her room - she said she intended to return them.

FRANCIS SOAMES
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Green-street, Bethnal-green. I have a blanket pawned on the 12th of July, for 1s., and a pillow, on the 13th; and some cups and saucers, in the name of Haswell. I cannot swear to the prisoner.

EDWARD HALES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a blanket, pawned for 1s., and two or three other articles, they were all pawned by the prisoner.

JAMES ESSEX
. I am an officer, and took her; I found duplicates of the property in a pocket-book in her room.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Confined Three Months .

1725.
JOSEPH LEE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 2 sheets, value 4s. , the goods of
Isaac Mussell
.

ANN MUSSELL
. I am the wife of
Isaac Mussell
. The prisoner lodged on our ground floor; I missed these sheets from my first floor room.

HENRY DUPLIEX
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, pawned by the prisoner on the 28th of August.

WILLIAM ALLEN
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house; he said, "I acknowledge I took them, but do not know what I did with them;" he bears a good character.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I beg for mercy.
GUILTY. Aged 3 .

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

1725.
GEORGE WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 2 shirts, value 30s. , the goods of
James Soper
.

JAMES SOPER
. I live at Edmonton
. On the 24th of July, on coming home, between seven and eight o'clock, I heard our drying ground had been robbed. I applied to the constable, and next day I saw a pawnbroker, who described a person to me. I saw the prisoner carrying a bundle on the road, and had him secured, and taken into a public-house; I asked what he had in the bundle; he said two shirts; I opened them, and said they were mine. I had the fellow shirt on - I never saw him before.

JOSEPH DOSSETT
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner with the bundle, containing two shirts.

MARY MAINE
. I am a servant to Mr. Soper; I hung the linen out about one o'clock, and missed it between two and three.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

1727.
BENJAMIN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 1 coat, value 20s., and 2 books, value 1s. , the goods of
John Elkins
, his master .
The prisoner pleaded GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined One Month .

1728.
LUCY CATHERINE BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 2 blankets, value 5s.; 2 pillows, value 4s.; 1 table-cloth, value 1s. 6d.; 2 pillow-cases, value 9d.; 2 spoons, value 4s.; 2 sheets, value 6s., and 1 candlestick, value 6d. , the goods of
James Rowell
.

MELYAR SOPHIA ROWELL
. I am the wife of
James Rowell
, a cabinet-maker : we live in Smith-street, Somers'-town
. The prisoner hired some apartments of me, ready furnished - she paid me very well. I went into her room two or three days previous to her being taken, and missed this property - some of it has been found.

WILLIAM BAKER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Somers'-town. I have two blankets, a sheet, and a candlestick, pawned at different times by a woman, in the name of Brown. I have a table-cloth, which I can swear was pawned by the prisoner for 1s. 6d., in July.

GEORGE HAVILL
. I am a constable. I was sent for on the 23d of August, and took the prisoner - she gave up some duplicates of this property, and said she intended to redeem them on Friday.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How long had she been with you? A. Between four and five months: she might be poorly, but never had any medical attendant - there was 2l. 13s. due when I spoke to her; she had given me notice to quit, and the expiration of the notice would have been in two days. I will swear that the first time I missed any thing from her apartments, was on the Tuesday night previous to the Friday on which the notice would have expired. I spoke to her of it on the Wednesday - I gave her into custody on Thursday.

Prisoner's Defence. My remittances did not come in, and I pawned some sheets, which the prosecutor knew of- and the day I was committed here, she told me she was not a fool, she knew I had done it. Poverty alone induced me so far to forget myself.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Three Months .

1729.
MARY LANG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 piece of gold, of the value of 10s.; 1 sovereign, and 3 pieces of foreign silver coin, value 4s. 6d. , the property of
Michael Moore
.

MICHAEL MOORE
. I am a sailor , and Italian . I came here in the Saucy Jack, and have got no ship since. On the 15th of August, about eleven o'clock at night, I was in White's-yard; I met the prisoner, who took me to a house - I was very tired - I took off my jacket, and put it on a chair. I had some foreign gold and silver in the pocket - I fell on the bed, and went to sleep directly - she was then in the room. I awoke in about half an hour, and saw her over-hauling my things; I jumped out of bed, felt my pocket, and the money was gone; she put the money into her mouth; I tried to get it out, but could not. I called the watchman, who came; she then said, "I give charge of this man for ill-using me:" I said, "I give charge of this woman for robbing me;" I did not find all my money- there was 9s. 6d. taken from her mouth at the watch-house. I lost all the rest - I had not given her any thing - I was to pay her for the night's lodging certainly, but it was not agreed what. I lost one sovereign, and some Columbian money, and 9s. 6d. in silver.

CHRISTOPHER WARD
. I heard the cry of Murder! and Watch! - I went to the room, and the prisoner said, "I give charge of this man for ill-using me;" and he said, "You have got 1l. 14s. 6d. English money of mine, and if you don't give it me, he shall take you to the watch-house." I took them both to the watch-house - I saw no silver but what the prosecutor had in his hand, and which he said he got from her month - her mouth was bleeding - they were quarrelling together.

JOHN DANGATE
. I was the watch-house keeper. The prisoner was brought to me, and the prosecutor accused her of robbing him of 14s. 6d., one sovereign, two quarter-dollars, and one half-dollar - the prisoner said she had not got any thing upon her person. I searched her, and found in the left side of her mouth (which was bleeding) 9s. 6d. in silver, and there was sixpenny worth of copper in her hand; this half-dollar, and two quarter-dollars, the prosecutor gave me, and told me he took them out of her left hand.

Prisoner. When he got up into the room he asked me for a light, and said he thought he had lost some money - he pulled out a 5l. note, and said, "Some of those girls in the public-house have robbed me;" I said, "Recollect you have not lost it here;" and then he sent me for something to drink, and gave me 6s. I did not rob him - he was asleep above an hour; and if I had been disposed to rob him, I should have taken all his money.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1730.
CHARLES LINSCOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 silver spoon, value 14s. , the goods of
Mary Clay
, widow .

MARY CLAY
. I am a widow, and live in Wapping
, with my son, who is a baker; the prisoner used to come to the shop very often; he came into the bake-house, on the 6th of June; some of the girls gave him something to eat; in two days afterwards the spoon was missing.

MARY ISRAEL
. I keep a silversmith's shop. The prisoner came into my shop, two or three months ago - I cannot tell whether it was June or July - I was before the Magistrate, but do not know when - I have a very short memory.

Q. Did you state to the Magistrate, at the examination, on the 24th of August: - "The prisoner came to my shop, and threw the spoon on my counter - I asked where he got it; he said his mother sent him with it?" A. Yes; it was broken. I do not know his mother - I weighed it; it was 13/4 oz. - I paid him 8s. 3d.; here is the spoon - I live in at No. 4, Upper East Smithfield, near the Mint - I deal in clothes as well as silver - I did not ask where his mother lived. I sell my silver to the refiners.
Q. Is this spoon worn out? A. It is; because it is broken; it is not worn out.
Prisoner. Q. What day did you buy it of me? A. I cannot tell.

RALPH CLAY
. I am the prosecutrix's son; she informed me she had lost a spoon. I was accidentally passing Israel's shop, about a week after, and saw a spoon which appeared to me to be the same. I got an officer, who went and brought up Israel; the prisoner had been in my employ, and was discharged on the 6th. If this spoon is ours, it is much disfigured since I saw it last. I told the Magistrate the spoon produced there was mine - I cannot swear to it now. I knew the spoon I saw in the window was my mother's; if this is the same, it has been much worn, and knocked about since. I believe the one I saw to be ours, but the parts of this do not fit the bowl.

MARK ISRAEL
. The spoon has been in my possession since - I have not altered it.
- JEFFREY. I was before the Magistrate - Israel produced a spoon there.
NOT GUILTY .

1731.
JAMES M'DOUGAL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 bundle of small-hand paper, value 10s. , the goods of
Joseph Bargett
.

THOMAS WEBB
. I am a watchman of Newman-street
. On the 24th of August, about half-past nine o'clock, at night I saw the prisoner take a parcel from under his arm from Bardgett's shop-door; he reached in, and took it - I sprang my rattle, and called Stop thief! he threw it down in Well-street, and I took him.

JOHN BARGETT
. I am a tailor . This paper laid on my shop floor; the door was shut.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

1732.
HENRY PERRY
and
JOHN NOBLE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 table-cloth, value 4d.; 2 petticoats, value 4s.; 1 cap, value 4d.; 1 pair of stays, value 4s.; 1 bed-gown, value 1s.; 1 shift, value 1s. 6d.; 2 shirts, value 4s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 6d., and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
Mary Summerfield
, widow .

MARY SUMMERFIELD
